sub.page.body.para: We think of an arrow in \RNr[n] as exactly what the word suggests: a perfectly straight object with a tail and a tip. Thus the location of an arrow in space is determined by two points, namely

li.para: a point, say P, which marks the tail of the arrow,
a point, say Q, which marks the tip of the arrow

sub.page.body.para: We write \Arrw{PQ} for the arrow which has its tail at P and its tip at Q. – The picture below shows three such arrows.
For example, the pink horizontal arrow on the right has its tail at a point named R, and it has its tip at a point named S. So we write \Arrw{RS} for the arrow joining R to S. Similarly,

li.para: \Arrw{PQ} denotes the arrow joining the point P to the point Q.
\Arrw{TU} denotes the arrow joining the point T to the point U.
